text: The US was never ahead of China in the fight against climate change. The fair way to compare the 2 countries would be to compare on a per capita basis and account for the fact that much of the factories in China are there to make affordable things for the rest of the world.  Even when you include all the factory or industrial emissions, the U.S. is still the leader in per capita emissions, with about 17.6 tons of GHGs emitted per singular person. By comparison, China stands at 10.5 tons per citizen.  How is this possible you ask. Well, most urban Chinese use mass transportation such as trains, subways, or buses instead of driving their own cars. Many of the mass transit systems including highspeed rail are electrified which further reduces emissions. Many still ride bikes or e-bikes or e-scooters.  Many don't have heat in the winter or AC in the summer. Many don't have the luxury to take showers every day. The list goes on and on.  Ural Chinese work on the farm from their villages so they either walk or bike to their fields.  Bulk of the emissions are from the factories that make the stuff we consume outside of China.

(Whether the earth is cooling or heating up is not within the control of man. The earth is a highly automated machine, with heating from the sun above and volcanoes below. Climate change was planned to tax all peoples of the world. Now, the UN has already Carbon Credit that nations can pay or buy to enable them to produce smoke beyond certain limits. It was originally named Global Warming, but changed when some wise guys presented data that the world is actually cooling down.) 

NO OZONE LAYER PROTECTING US FROM UV IN THE SUN
There's no ozone layer atop our atmosphere protecting us from the sun. At the top of our atmosphere is hydrogen2, the lightest gas, and possibly ionized hydrogen.

The scientific "fact" that says there's ozone layer protecting us from the UV rays of the sun is false. This is indicated by the list below of the molecular weights of gases.

As the list below indicates, heavy ozone can exist mainly near the ground, together with carbon dioxide or smoke.

Science is a religion that feeds on ignorance. And they have been keeping us ignorant throughout history.

MOLECULAR WEIGHTS OF GASES:
 	
hydrogen  1.00794 g/mol  
hydrogen2 2.016 g/mol
     
helium  4.002602 g/mol        	

oxygen 15.9994 g/mol

air 28,96 g/mol
oxygen2 32 g/mol    

nitrogen2 28.013 g/mol

carbon dioxide 44.010 g/mol
ozone 47.9982 g/mol

Conclusion: there's no ozone layer in the sky that's destroyed by refrigerants, etc.

Source:
https://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/molecular-mass-air-d_679.html

text:
The real DILEMA is the McPherson paradox (see www.guymcpherson.com).  IF we cut emissions and clear the skies of particulate and aerosol masking what will happen to climate change?  We have a tentative answer. Due to the COVID-19 "lockdowns" of industry and transportation, increased solar radiation reached the Earth's land surface and shallow sea. This caused  record level heating and water evaporation of both. Arrival of record-breaking monsoon and typhoon rains, summer snow, and hail flooded Southern and Eastern China destroying two crops (one was a replant) in a row. Northern China (Inner Mongolia) experienced drought and locust plagues. China's government, wisely, bought massjve amounts of grain from the USA and India to stave off food shortages. Meanwhile, Australia, China's largest supplier of air-polluting coal. Burning coal baked in China's prolonged drought, record wildfires, and finally flooding rainfall. The Western USA continues to experience prolonged drought and record wildfires. Texas, USA,  experienced record cold that wiped out this year's  South Texas' winter vegetable crop. IF this "bad weather" continues, expect food prices to continue rising in wealthy countries and shortages in poorer countries as they compete for shrinking food stocks.
        We listened to the economists instead of ecologists. "Development," irrespective of political system, requires GROWTH, infinite growth on a finite planet. And, that is impossible. So, we have "mined" the Earth and destroyed the very ecosystem that supports us. We are well into Earth's 8th mass extinction and it includes us,  old geologist

text:
These Western media reports are always missing the real strengths of China. The reporters are too thick to understand or prefer not to see how China actually works.

Its not just top down "authoritarian" dictate but the ability to hold to its commitments where you see the US pulling out of its treaties with trump and unable to commit to long term goals.

BUT the heft and size of China and its market also provides these policies the room to achieve their goals when unlocked to market forces.

Solar panels etc all end up cheaper bc of intense competition from small enterprises plus the huge size of the market making the cost of green economy affordable. And when China pulls into the lead in these areas, bc of the price points it can achieve domestically, it has a double advantage offering countries world wide equal economic solutions in environmental tech.

The other thing to take note is that whilst the proportion of coal power is still high, many of the coal plants that have come on line over last decade are "Clean Coal" power stations which are less pollutant. whilst still no where near ideal, it is a temporary solution will better tech can come in to replace it (such as Nuclear fission)

And finally worth noting whilst china remains for now the biggest polluter, never mentioned in Western media reporting conveniently - the United States is the HIGHEST per Capita polluter by a wide margin and the polluter with the most CO2 stock.

In any case both countries need to work together to provide solutions rather than at cross purposes. Whether the US will be able to make that adjustment remains to be seen as most of the recent Trade war shennanigans etc were started by the US and its own insecurities plus inaccurate reading of China.

Hopefully the Biden administration will be more adult and less zero sum game with its approach.

text:
Because the US does not produce nearly enough home-grown talent to sustain its economy. It relies on its image of the Land of Opportunity, Land of Innovation, American Dream and its bright future. But we already see this is no longer true. Fewer and fewer people want to live there - immigration from developed countries is down, foreign students are down. China, on the other hand, is seen as the future.
Unless the US manages to drastically turn this image around, its economy will suffer. Its companies will no longer be competitive with foreign competition, they will have to either move or close.
Tesla and SpaceX are shining examples of US innovation, but Musk has said that he would not even be allowed in the US if he arrived from South Africa today.

text:
@Jay Gee  You are correct that China has stolen IP. But here are some things you might not be aware of:
https://www.carscoops.com/2019/11/from-copycats-to-collectibles-kaizen-and-the-rise-of-the-japanese-auto-industry/

Now we jump to present day China:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0StTrsdoD3c
^From an engineering perspective, I think battery swapping this frequently has limitations, especially when there’s mud and snow.
But this is a novel process that hasn’t been done anywhere else, so China couldn't have copied this word-for-word.
From a capabilities point of view, China has reached a point where it doesn’t have to copy much anymore.
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-57211001
^Mars landing is also hard to copy. Typically to copy something you need to get your hands on the product and disassemble it.
Of course this is difficult when U.S rovers are not for commercial sale, and the functioning ones are in space lol.
And every orbital launch is different, so it’s not like you can just blindly follow a blueprint.

Here are some more links:

text:
From my perspective and from what I see, there is also another underlying and simple reason, why China is leading in alternative energy/clean energy development:

Fossil fuels are not reliable.


Why? Simply put, most of the fossil fuels are controlled by hostile nations, unstable leaders or antagonistic parties. There aren't that many stable and reliable suppliers of fossil fuels to China. That's why, the best course of action for China, is to grab the bull by its horns, and actually develop alternative sources of energy that is within their own control and reduce dependency on importing these energy.

text: My parents live in a small city in sw China. Our apt was installed a solar panel water heater back in 2002, and we had to share with three other neighbors, so sometimes in winter it really wasn’t enough hot water, and the pipe would freeze up. Then we moved into a single house around 2006 and we installed a newer generation solar panel for our house. It’s pretty reliable and no longer freeze up during winter time with the insulated pipes. Enough hot water is provided for the whole family to take daily showers, pretty good. And it cost about ¥250k to install the whole system.

text:
Somethings to take into account
I am not an expert on China, environmental expert, or fields related to this

1. China is extremely corrupt and will most likely lie on their statistics.
Companies that violate these agreements could probably not get punished because they know officials in the government.

2.  China burns mostly dirty compared to the US clean coal.

3.  Just because you implement more clean energy could actually have a counterproductive effect.
For example, if it takes x amount of carbon to produce a solar panel then will you have to consider that in the statistics.
Also, solar panels don't work during the night and wind turbines don't work without the wind. So you would have to turn on the coal-burning plants.
Which could result in more carbon being produced overall. This happened in Germany 
https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamesconca/2017/10/10/why-arent-renewables-decreasing-germanys-carbon-emissions/
This is forbs so take it as you will

4. Our climate models are just models and we do not know how reliable they are or how good they are. Especially for long time periods after today, like 50 years.
This doesn't mean you shouldn't trust Environmental scientists consider the error.

 All I am trying to say here is that this narrative of China being the good guys and the US/Donald Trump/Republicans being the bad guys is just absurd.
It is more complicated than that.

text:
From BBC news. US top of the garbage pile in global waste crisis. 
US citizens produce 773kg per head of population, roughly 12% of the global total. Their output is three times that of their Chinese counterparts and seven times more than people living in Ethiopia. Per head of population the worst offenders are the US, as Americans produce three times the global average of waste, including plastic and food.
When it comes to recycling, America again lags behind other countries, only re-using 35% of solid waste. The US is the only developed nation with waste generation that outstrips its ability to recycle. 
Other European countries, including the Netherlands, Switzerland, France and Germany, feature on the list. The UK ranks 14th in the waste index generating 482kg of household waste per person every year.
https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-48838699

The United States, the European Union, Australia, and Japan are shipping large consignments of plastic and other waste to Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, Turkey, India, and Vietnam after China refused to recycle them last year. 
Unable to cope with the influx of trash, it's being buried, burned, or unscientifically processed, polluting water, air and soil in these regions.
Basic human needs such as clean water, clean air and safe food are jeopardized by improper waste management practices. "They (Asian countries) don't want to be the world's dumping ground anymore"
In the early stage, China did not have legal means to curb the import of foreign garbage, but when China issued a ban on hazardous foreign waste, ...
U.S. asks China not to implement ban on foreign garbage https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-environment-usa-idUSKBN1GZ2WI

text:
Carbon taxes are folly. Deforestation is the problem. Reforestation or land set aside the solution. I’ve witnessed it with my own eyes. 

Born and bred in Africa I witnessed much of the climate change in Zimbabwe as forests were cut down for grain and tobacco cultivation and 80% of the land changed to grassland and semi-desert. The EU land set aside restores nature’s powers over the climate, fixing carbon dioxide and stabilising temperatures and rainfall.  Why else is earth’s atmospheric carbon dioxide just 0.04% when it straddles between Venus and Mars each with atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations in excess of 90%? Carbon dioxide is not the demon, it is plant food and plants work for us providing us with food and controlling our climate to be most favourable for life. Carbon dioxide and fossil fuels are just side actors, just like police cars and ambulances are to an accident scenes. Just because police cars and ambulances are present at every accident scene does not mean that they caused them. The same with carbon dioxide and fossil fuels, they were mere agents of deforestation but deforestation was the cause of environmental changes. 

So the solution to gaining control over our environment is strengthening nature. 

The first method can be used by you personally to indirectly alter the climate for the better. Change to a keto diet and minimise your carbohydrate intake. This will not only improve your health but more importantly incentivise farmers to plant trees which bind soil and provide nuts and seeds for your keto diet. If you choose a high carbohydrate diet, farmers will respond by cutting down forests to grow grain for your food. So by altering your food intake to a keto or paleo diet, you alter the food chain and thus ultimately the climate. 

See the best keto diet here https://youtu.be/gxLSxt2IKiQ

The second (macro) solution can bring about climate improvement as follows. 

1) Build plant factories to feed 7.8 billion people and liberate land and water for forests
https://youtu.be/dnCQuwCtqJg
https://youtu.be/qGyAeqdkkbw
https://youtu.be/ESuzrY2abAw

See examples of working plant factories
https://youtu.be/5clOYWsNhhk
https://youtu.be/4CMfPLEtQMQ

2) Use cattle herds to revitalise soil
https://youtu.be/vpTHi7O66pI

3) Use goats to reduce fire dangers in forests
https://youtu.be/g9yiclBCxMo 

4) Use agrivoltaics to turn deserts into meadows with solar panels
https://youtu.be/XwFB22r9zRo
https://youtu.be/CS3bBO05fpU

5) Use marine cloud seeding to moisten and seed ocean air for clouds and rain
https://youtu.be/Awf1W0-UMR4

6) Use minerals to assist salmon populations 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haida_Salmon_Restoration_Corporation

Don’t be misanthropic with the debunked carbon dioxide nonsense. Be positive. Be useful. Help flora and fauna control climate and don’t demonise plant food.

The optimum carbon dioxide lies between 150 ppm when plants die, and 4,000 ppm the comfortable limit for humans. We don’t know precisely what is best yet but we do know that with the superpower of flora and fauna we can live well.

text:
@Paul D.B   I didn’t even bother reading through your entire comment, since you have claimed false information reported by western news reports. But I don’t think it’s necessarily your fault, it’s just that you are living in a country full of lies. I don’t think China is absolutely the best country, or nether the world leader. But that doesn’t mean China is a total corruption. Life in China is getting better, having new goals and complete with actions(that western think the action is “bad” for the Chinese people aka the blame game). United States have always been the economic leader in the past decades, and preventing it from being claimed by communist countries is understandable. But not all countries are the same, what depends on a country is not the party, it’s determined by their common goal, and the people involved. Something that give China an advantage is that they are one big society, and yes, they only have one party, but that doesn’t necessarily mean the only party is bad. I am not saying democracy is bad by any mean, it’s that many people don’t know what politics decisions to make, and putting them in risk is not responsible.

At the end, I want to say the United States seems to go along with the blame game, and people you called ass kissers are the people who wanted to make a change to the world, including the United States, not limit our innovation just because it’s an idea from a country with different political ideology.

text:
@Da Cheez  Oh look, yet another westerner who's total knowledge of China consists exclusively of a few western articles he's read and who's never set foot there, and yet still is totally certain he knows what's really going on there ("literally", lol)! You must be so proud of typing "China Uighurs" into Google and now feel so informed. Let me guess, you also actually believe that the Chinese govt harvests organs, has absolutely no claim over Taiwan, and has turned HK into an Orwellian hellhole, right? Your comment is a typical display of lazy ignorance towards China.

There's more and more evidence shattering most western media claims about the Uighur situation and exposing them as a broad disinformation campaign led by the CIA/NED (surprise). For example, the oft cited number of "2 million Uighurs in concentration camps" comes from exactly two sources: 1) The World Uighur Congress, which is almost wholly funded by the NED and got this claim from "western media estimates" (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A8uZZjB4kfM), and 2) Adrian Zenz, a far-right religious nutjob who literally believes he's on a mission assigned by god to take down China. Additionally, the Uyghur population in Xinjiang has actually DRAMATICALLY increased in the past few decades. So what’s next, are you gonna show me the satellite images of the “mass graves” being dug in Xinjiang?

And here are some more truth-bombs for you: Nearly all Muslim-majority countries applaud China's re-education efforts in Xinjiang, and only developed western countries (who don't really care about Muslims if were being honest, especially the US whose war on terror btw has killed around 500,000 people in the Middle East by now) condemn it. Also, China has more mosques per muslim than ANY OTHER COUNTRY on earth (US the lowest among major countries)? Source: https://www.islamicreliefcanada.org/mosque-list/ On top of that, contrary to popular belief in the west (and this might make your head explode), China actually treats its minorities exceptionally well overall: Did you know the one-child policy didn't apply to minorities in China? Flat out didn’t apply to all minorities, no questions asked. And their affirmative action program for minorities would put the US’ affirmative action to shame: Did you know minorities can receive extra marks on the gaokao if they want, just for being a minority? It’s the most important exam a Chinese student will ever take (much bigger deal than the SAT). On top of that, many minorities can have their tuition COMPLETELY WAIVED! Also, did you know almost every school - be it universities, high schools, even freaking middle schools - offers minorities their own cafeterias complete with their own foods? Yes, China actually treats its minorities awfully well, much better than America does at least.

How about doing some actual research instead of parroting hollow western media talking points?

I wouldn't give up having a car to ride a damn bus, no matter how good the bus system is. I'm sure people on the bus in China would also rather have a car...  Living in a tiny apartment with no place to store a car or have a lawn is not a better style of living, just because it's "less wasteful". I'm not a pawn in some organization game that can just be stuck on some tiny space because its "more efficient". I work hard so I can have a big house, a lawn, afford to water it, have a car, go where I want in it, and live my life to the fullest. Other countries don't have that opportunity, because they don't have the freedom or economic ability to do so. It's not for the desire to be cleaner, they are just acting like that because they can't achieve the same standards of living, and they won't give their people the freedom to do so.
author: Paul D.B

text: @Paul D.B  Let's first put the question of whether your way of thinking is correct or not aside. The minimum requirement is not to hold double standards and be a hypocrite. The Americans accused China of consuming too much carbon fuels and claiming that if China adopts the American way of life, the environment cannot sustain that level of energy consumption, and that is double standards. Americans like you emphasize freedom while your government points its fingers to almost every matter in the world, and that is hypocrisy. Now let's go back to your statement. Do I agree with the expert on the statement that China cannot follow the US? Yes, because we all live in the same globe and what you do affects me and what I do affects you. So no, you don't have the right to consume whatever energy you can produce. It's not about freedom, it's about shared responsibility. I live in Southern California, the wildfire is a clear sign that what we do affects others.

text:
Visited China in 2002 (post WTO), 2009 (post Olympics and high speed rail investment) and 2016 (midst of their green energy push), and last in 2018. Frankly, the urban landscape has changed by leaps and bounds. Shenzhen is the showcase city for EV, I was surprised at how many taxis were running on electric. High speed rail providing seamless connection between hubs and nodes. 

I can see why the US containment strategy has shifted towards Chinese tech during trump’s administration. Without a serious commitment by US politicians to ramp up infrastructure stateside, it’s a matter of time before Chinese green tech will dominate globally.

RankCountryCO2 emissions (total)1China10.06GT2United States5.41GT3India2.65GT4Russian Federation1.71GT5Japan1.16GT6Germany0.75GT7Islamic Republic of Iran0.72GT8South Korea0.65GT9Saudi Arabia0.62GT10Indonesia0.61GT11Canada0.56GT12Mexico0.47GT13South Africa0.46GT14Brazil0.45GT15Turkey0.42GT16Australia0.42GT17United Kingdom0.37GT18Poland0.34GT19France0.33GT20Italy0.33GT21Kazakhstan0.32GTAll emissions from 2018. Fuel combustion only. GT = Metric gigatons

The rankings change when we account for the population of each country (ie, per capita emissions).

2018 rankings by per capita emissions

RankCountryCO2 emissions (total)1Saudi Arabia18.48T2Kazakhstan17.60T3Australia16.92T4United States16.56T5Canada15.32T6South Korea12.89T7Russian Federation11.74T8Japan9.13T9Germany9.12T10Poland9.08T11Islamic Republic of Iran8.82T12South Africa8.12T13China7.05T14United Kingdom5.62T15Italy5.56T16Turkey5.21T17France5.19T18Mexico3.77T19Indonesia2.30T20Brazil2.19T21India1.96TAll emissions from 2018. Fuel combustion only. T = Metric tons

The picture that emerges from these figures is one where—in general—developed countries and major emerging economy nations lead in total carbon dioxide emissions.
However, developed nations typically have high carbon dioxide emissions per capita, while some developing countries lead in the growth rate of carbon dioxide emissions. These uneven contributions to the climate crisis are at the core of the challenges the world community faces in finding effective and equitable solutions to global warming.

text: In 2018, I went to China for the first time.  One evening in Shanghai, I was walking from The Bund back to the hotel.  I stopped at a traffic light at an intersection.  Tens, if not hundreds, of small mopeds ran in front of me.  Suddenly, I felt something was very strange.  There was no engine and tailpipe noise.  I stood at the spot for a good 5-7 minutes observing.  I was very surprised that all those mopeds are ELECTRIC.  I don't know when they started phasing/forcing out the ICE mopeds which are still very popular to this day in late 2020 in other parts of Asia.  China is certainly leading by example, and more importantly, without pushing forward something only to be pulled back a number of years later after an election.

author: a9udn9u

text: @a9udn9u  every metric needs to be taken with a grain of salt. In China, the worst pollution is coming from the northeast, it doesn’t make sense to tax the opening of a factory in western China because they have the highest emission. Population can be misleading too, because if say you have one island as a country of 1 person and build a factory that services the world, it’s going to have a really high per capita emission which is unfair. When you look at per area and per capita metrics together, you see population density as one of the leading contributors no matter where you are in the world. Concentration of emission in a smaller area over a shorter period of time is much worse than the same amount of emission spread out over a large area over longer time periods, which is China’s model, the western half of China is actually very clean, all the pollution is concentrated in the east. The US never had weeks of yellow sky when they were industrializing.

author: Allen Wright

text:
@Free Speech  there is PM2.0, PM2.5, and PM10 which have nothing to do with Carbon emissions and China has horrible air quality. 

partical pollution PM2.0 is ground-level ozone, carbon monoxide, and sulfur dioxide 
China is at 79.88

 PM2.5 represents the fine particles such as the toxic compounds and the heavy metals which are caused by the fires and through smelting the metals. 
 China average is 39.12

PM10 represents the particles which are found in the air and we think them as pollution. There might be numerous kinds of particles such as dirt, pollen, smoke and mold etc. 
 China
Annual mean PM10 ug/m3 is  98
Above or Below world average of 71ug/m3 china is 27
Percentage of urban area coverage is around 24%

And if we go by cities 
China has two cities in the  hazardous range of 300-500
40 cities in the very unhealthy range of 201-300
170 cities in the unhealthy range of 151-200
90 cities in unhealthy for sensitive groups 101-150
130 cities in the moderate range 51-100
27 cities in good range 1-50

For comparison America has 
7 cities in the index of 101-185
160 cities with moderate air quality 51-100
340 cities below 50 making it good. 

All these News updates are completely false whether its pro and con China or USA. 
Yes China is researching green technology but they also are the largest importers of oil and natural gas and if America wanted to over a week could shut the lights off in China.
China is also building record number coal factories. 
People will also say but China wasn't a part of the industrial revolution. Well China had their own industrial revolution 700-900 years ago and its nobodies fault they had a revolution that pushed for an Agrarian society. 

Some also say China will become global leaders, not without a military to keep stable trade. 
People who are pro China also criticizes American wars in the middle east which China profited off of. 
They have a dwindling youth population in comparison to massive group of people entering retirement in 2-10 years. 
No consumer economy. China relies on imports materials for their majority export economy. 
China also relies on import of food because their arable land needs imported fertilizers and can't support their population. 
The only method of global trade is South China Sea which navigates through over 7 countries which is why they've been militarily dominating neighboring countries economic zones and without America their trade would be diminished.

author: Talk the Talk

text: @Talk the Talk   Oh Poor you . If only you knew the intricacies of Political Thought and Theory. China's communism has morphed and adjusted to the current times. I suggest you read more about the phenomenon rather than sprouting unscientific BS. The Chinese Communism had faced an existential crisis in the 1970s. The party leaders clearly saw that Capitalism was better at growth and rise in living standards. However they were also hell bent on keeping their power intact. The only effort was that no more rise of another populist demagogue. So starting from 1978 slow liberalisation of the economy began. Privatisations of Industry and agriculture was initiated. However unlike the liberal capitalist system that was been adapted by many other countries, the CCP itself acted like a autocratic company, meaning that you can do business freely but "with the permission" and consent of the party. Also they were required to have a Politburo member from Beijing to supervise and keep a close watch on these foreign corporations. So the SEZs that are in China were not really "Special" per se. They had to just be silent and the CCP would allow them to penetrate the Chinese market as much as they wished. Also over the years Chinese Politburo members have become businessmen and entrepreneurs. But all having ties to the CCP which has by now created good quality domestic private sector qualified enough to defeat traditional western competitors. So the CCP has ultimate control over Labour and most importantly, LAND. You probably don't know that there is a huge difference between theory and practice. Many people believe that Japan grew because of adapting American Style Capitalism while the truth is that it adopted the WW2 era Fascist style Window guidence system of War Economy.

text: @Lu5ck  No form of energy will completely satisfy the need of any major countries, you need to maintain multiple forms of energy: fuel, hydroelectric, nuclear, solar, wind, etc. The question is the proportion. Some countries depends mainly on burning fuels to generate electricity (e.g., US) while others got more of hydroelectricity (e.g., China) or nuclear (e.g., EU). Your claim that "increasing energy costs and producing more carbon footprint" unsubstantiated. It only serves the purpose of finger pointing game and has no merit whatsoever. If your logic works, meaning we all need to switch to one form of energy, then we will all end up burning more fuels like the US, which would requires 7-8 Earth to provide the ecosystem to make it sustainable. Your theory is as unsustainable as the energy strategy of the US.

text:
@Lu5ck  You have lost and you try to divert the attention into irrelevant details about Germany and discharging verbal abuses. You use a lot of words to say nothing. That kind of tactics will not work with me. 

Let's focus on your argument that is based on lies and half-truth:

1) you claim China's effort to cut emission by going green / reducing carbon density is useless because its GDP is still growing. Then what about the USA, and Taiwan, and Japan? GDP growth has not top out in any countries. So single out China for attack?

2) you insist on assigning the C footprint of the US and other importing countries to China, C footprint is based on actual consumption, not based on production. You finger-pointing here is like someone living in Rocky Mountain blaming Detroit and Pittsburg for their own C footprint: the car they drive is made in Detroit using steel from Pittsburg. You simply distort the concept of C footprint to suit your need. You are treating everyone else here as kids in kindergartens. 

3) you claim green technology will not reduce carbon emission, instead, it will increase it because of construction etc. You are essentially saying everyone in green energy is an idiot, the anti-environmental faction is smart. That is total BS. You only trying to find excuse for countries like Taiwan, which is doing nothing to reduce emission, and the US under Trump, which place business interest above humanity. At the same time, you want to discredit China for its effort. If you think that is smart, you better to think again. Nobody will buy that.

BTW, nuclear tech is not exactly green. SO you are cheating again. Your entire argument is based on lies. You cannot save it.

text: @disbsam333  "dump chemicals ... with state backing" is unfounded. The reality is that the state regulation is not strictly enforced. The real issue is that the west transfer the dirty industries to the 3rd world by tightening the regulation, and enjoy the product while complaining the pollution. I personally would love to see those dirty industries go away from Asia, and let them go back to US and Europe. If that happens, either the west has to close its eyes to pollution to enjoy the same low price, or to pay more for the same thing. I don't care which way they chose. But Asian countries love to keep those jobs because they think there could be instability without it. This kind of thought is also unfounded. The demand for the industrial jobs is a result of lower living standard in the rural area, which pushes the farmers into the cities. If the governments pay more attention to rural development instead of using dirty industries as an outlet for surplus population, there would not be so much demand for jobs and better stability. The very fact that the west cannot stop importing those "crap" from the 3rd world shows this is exactly what they want to do. If someday Asian government tighten regulation, the west would not be happy about it. That explains why the west bashes China when it ban import of dirty recycled materials. It's all Hypocrisy after all.

India is even less industrialized. China in the last few years has been home to the many of the most polluted cities in the world. Just take a look at some skyline photos of chinese cities. It seems they have started to get better, but that didn’t start until 2015, after noticing that you can barely see anything more than a mile away in their cities. Having s larger country should also mean you are more aware of how that will affect pollution so I don’t believe having more people should make it okay to pollute freely. China has been horrible pollution wise for the last 40 years, but it looks like they are starting to slow their pollution which is a good sign

text: Fight against climate is a difficult challenge.  The first would be basis of measurement, should it be emission per million population, per GDP, or per land area？  How should pollution in the past be accounted for (it would not be fair to those who have little pollution in the past, particularly if due to underdevelopment)?  The second would be the unnecessary hostile view western world has towards China which is the largest polluter by nation but not by per million population.  A third would be measure to appease those who have not polluted in the past but needed it to develop its country, a notable one would be India who already has the most polluted cities but deserve its right to develop to improve their own lives.  Hmm... what's more？  Wonder who is holding those patents of green energy technologies and how much they have collected over the years in the name of curing the earth, just wonder how much are they willing to "really" save the world with free patent fees and technology transfer?

Jay Liu

text:
@Jay Liu  as usual, denying everything wrong with China. I never said America was immune, but China’s bathing in more propaganda then it likes to admit. As I’ve said, there are many news sources in China that are partly (or completely) government funded. You aren’t immune. If anything, you’re consuming the pro-China rhetoric like an elephant drinks water.

There is no question that Uyghur genocide is happening. Don’t deny it. It’s common knowledge at this point.

I’m more than aware of the history of Taiwan. That still doesn’t excuse the fact that Taiwan is a sovereign nation with its own constitution, culture, and people.

And back to the original point, China is far more corrupt than America. Your courts have no jury, and lower level courts can be easily corrupted. Chinese judges receive guidance from the 
government and the ruling party regularly, particularly when it comes to politically sensitive cases.

Your businesses rely on bribes and other types of financial fraud. Companies report that police services are unreliable in protecting them from crime and enforcing the law. Further, two-thirds of business report paying for security in China. Abuses of power among police officers were rarely prosecuted.
author: Sunlight Spear

text:
@Sunlight Spear  Nobody's denying "everything" is wrong with China. We know there are rampant corruption and there have been efforts to rein in the problem. That's one of the fundamental differences between China and the U.S. We look inward, and the U.S. look outward - when there are problems with corruption domestically, you report about corruption in China; when there are incompetency domestically - you bring up issues about "China cheating" and "China stealing". Here's the thing: if your country is so free of corruption and so efficient, why are folks dying left and right, with new records being set on a daily basis? Why are the healthcare system so dysfunctional that some folks are better off dying than to live with debt? Why does so many cops and government officials get away with committing crimes?  I think the U.S. should take care of its own problems first instead of constantly bashing China. Even media coverage about China's advances in environmental improvements must come with gray skies and words like "corruption". It's no wonder you hold such a strong and negative opinion toward my country. All I can say is buy yourself a plane ticket some day and visit China. That's what it took for my sister's very anti-China co-worker to see how wrong his view was.

I'm going to end things here; we're going to end up squandering a lot of time replying back and forth, and I have some reports to type up. Have a great day.
author: Jay Liu

text: @Jay Liu  America does have problems, I was never denying that. You, however, inflated them. The healthcare system can be improved, true, but America still has the best healthcare facilities in the world. Corona is also an issue, but that will be solved soon when Biden gets into office. Statistically, less than six or so black people were killed by the police last year, and most of them were in self defense. And good looking buildings and infrastructure are just a disguise to cover up the true nature of China.

text:
What many people don’t realise is that when the West outsourced manufacturing to China, they also outsource the massive pollution that came with manufacturing. This essentially made China the world’s factory. Not only that, but the West also outsourced its recycling (ie trash) to China.

And then hypocritical Western regimes turned around and accused China of being a polluter and “stealing” their jobs!

There are very good reasons why businesses worldwide preferred China to manufacture their goods over other lower cost countries. Not only is labour in China affordable, but the people are also highly educated and hardworking. Supply chain in China is also second to none, and its government is hyper efficient.

Without China, the consumer goods we all enjoy today (especially high tech electronics) would be a lot less affordable.

text:
TLDR; Biden isn't gonna make any real change just by restricting things, development of technology will.
It's kind of naive to think that there will be any legislation that will give actual help. The most the government can actually do is force restrictions and hope that makes the difference. Now, the coal industry has deteriorated to the point that, even without those restrictions, it's use wouldn't ramp up to the point where it would increase carbon emissions. An option that would make a difference faster would nuclear energy, because Green options just aren't there yet. It takes time and development of those technologies. And, before you make any argument against nuclear energy, just look at Sweden.

text: @Magni Thorson  Biden has called for a massive investment in green energy. Idk what you're on about.
author: Thriving Anarchy

text: @Thriving Anarchy  There are two different types of investment: Either dumping money and buying up what is currently on market or buying into those technology firms. And there's more than one way to do both of those from a government standpoint. Either way, if any changes are immediate, that "investment" is half-assed and a cheap idea to buy votes. Because even with all the money in the world, it won't magically make the current level of green energy technology the next level in both cost efficiency and power generation efficiency. I'll be honest, you thinking that because Joe Biden calls for it, means both that he'll go through with it and that the "investment" at this point won't be a bureaucratic nightmare and a strain on taxpayer money with any beneficial changes being at most less than a whole percent in a change in CO2 admissions makes me think you're either not old enough to vote, or you just got into politics.

text: @Roy  For most of its 5000 year history, China was one of the richest, most advanced and most influential empires on the planet ('cept for the handful of times it broke up and fell into civil war). Meanwhile for most of its short history, the US has not been a superpower - and even for most of its brief history as a superpower, it hasn't been the sole superpower. The US has also been enormously gifted (more than almost any other country in the world) in a number of ways - large fertile plains, plentiful natural resources, weak neighbours and virtual immunity from overseas invasion thanks to two massive oceans, a fairly educated starting populace, the self-destruction of the world's other big powers in war or internal collapse, etc. Americans rarely realise how truly lucky they are. Many of those advantages China doesn't have, and it still led the world for most of civilized history (alongside India, the other great eastern power - most of the others, like Persia or Rome, didn't make it to the modern day). And despite being a superpower and the world's richest nation, the US still has poverty. Meanwhile China has carried out the largest and fastest poverty reduction exercise in human history, starting from a state more destitute than the US at independence. The US is very fortunate, but still has nothing on China's record. As for China's current system, even if it changes, that doesn't necessarily mean the country will "fall". And I say all this as someone who's not Chinese. Vanity does not do America any favours, and Americans would do well to remember that (also impedes effective diplomacy btw).

text:
In short, China actually cares about climate change and has the political backing to push for government subsidies for green projects even if they run at a deficit. In the US, it is purely capital driven. If its not a profit making model, it doesn't get the endorsement. 

One area of social economic benefit is high speed rail. They are for the most part not profitable but is the most efficient way to transport large groups of people between cities.

Im an engineering supervisor working in one of the biggest cities in the US’s utility  companies and watching the energy trends in China, its 100% clear China is the leader in green tech. 

Yes they pollute a lot, but they make everything there, its hard to not but they are also the most committed to clean energy. Shenzhen is a pilot program for the entire country to completely electrify. Its kind of amazing to watch. 

If Shenzhen is successful, I beleive in true Chinese fashion, they will replicate it in other large 1st tier cities across China

text:
@Francis McCorey  Maybe Mick is trying to show through those videos that in China, most people already accept that climate change is being accelerated by human activities and that they've already taken steps to produce noticeable improvements to the air quality in their cities. I agree with the point made in this CNBC post that China is ahead of the US in transitioning away from fossil fuel sources. It's tough for them because they still have to sustain a population 4 times that of the US and continue as the "factory of the world". As tough as it is, they are still forging ahead, as they had worked their way out of poverty. China is by far the top renewable energy country in the world - https://www.nsenergybusiness.com/features/top-renewable-energy-producing-countries/  However, it's still not enough because it's economy is still projected to grow.  That's why they are also heavily investing in nuclear energy, including nuclear fusion research -  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ktAiu-mMSoU

text:
Nuclear power cost 3x to build per MW than renewables plus storage.
https://reneweconomy.com.au/new-csiro-aemo-study-confirms-wind-solar-and-storage-beat-coal-gas-and-nuclear-57530/
This doesnt even count the ongoing fuel, maintenance, waste, decommissioning, and public liability insurance costs nuclear power has has that renewables do not.

Did you know that there isn't an insurance company in the world that will provide public liability cover for a major nuclear plant accident ? These insurance costs are real costs and are bourne by the public, ie, the ol' privatise the profits, while socialising the costs caper. No nuclear power plant exists anywhere without massive tax payer support.

Fun fact, various studies have shown that to fully decommision a nuclear power plant (if that is even possible) will cost more than all the income from all the electricity it made. This means that all of the 450 nuclear power plant sites around the world will now effectively be no go zones indefinitely.

All of these factors mean that the nuclear constrcution industry is dead, which it is. Did you know that the only Westinghouse Nuclear power division making money is its decommissioning division.

text:
Because using drastic measures to lower your own emissions means weakening your own nation economically in the short and mid-term, which puts you in a position of severe weakness economically, geopolitically, socially, militarily, etc. 

It's basically a global prisoner's dilemma where if everyone acted in the interest of everyone, the problem would be solved, but it takes just a single agent to act purely in their own immediate interest for everyone  to do so as well. This is especially problematic for any powerful country. There are no easy ways to fix this.

If you think solving climate change "just" takes this solution or that solution, you don't understand the nature of the problem.

text: The Chinese argument to that would be that, only a few decades ago, a significant portion of its population was living in absolute poverty. Whilst the famine caused by the Great Leap Forward was partly due to Mao's impractical economic aspirations, it is still the case that the largest famine in human history by death toll occurred in China in living memory. That is what development meant - going from basic subsistence to a decent quality of life. I can understand why environmental concerns took a backseat, even if I wish they hadn't.
